title: Philip Morris Stock Goes Flat After Muted Earnings Guidance
text:
Text size

Philip Morris International stock is edging lower on Thursday, following third-quarter earnings, although its chief financial officer tells Barron’s that the company is taking market share and seeing success with its reduced-risk products.

The back story. Philip Morris (ticker: PM) is up more than 18% in 2019, just trailing the broader market. The company’s previous earnings report came in better than expected, with management telling Barron’s that it was strategically moving toward a tobacco-free future and touting the success of its heat- not-burn iQOS device.

Analysts have been quick to praise the company’s strategy, and while regulations are always a concern with tobacco stocks, many argue that Philip Morris is actually in a good position to weather changes.

The stock had been rising ahead of the market, but that changed when rumors surfaced that it was considering recombining with Altria Group (MO), a little over a decade after the two companies split. Those talks were soon confirmed, and while some analysts pointed to synergies, the shareholders never got on board.

Both Philip Morris and Altria saw their stocks gain when the negotiations ended, as many saw the two better off as separate, with Philip Morris benefiting from strong international markets. Others think that iQOS will be key, especially as some consumers may see it as a safer alternative to vaping, which has been linked to potential health risks.

What’s new. Early Thursday, Philip Morris delivered better-than-expected third-quarter results, but the shares fell after the company provided muted fourth-quarter guidance on the conference call.

Looking ahead. CFO Martin King spoke with Barron’s following the report, and he says that while there are some timing issues affecting the fourth-quarter outlook, he urged investors to focus on the year as a whole: Excluding China and the U.S., industry volumes were down 2.5%, at the lower end of 2.5% to 3% estimates, and within that Philip Morris is seeing smaller declines, indicating a pickup in market share.

Editor's Choice

King also touted the company’s pricing power, as well as expanding margins—despite its investments in R&D—which he attributes to good cost controls. “You can see a very good underlying business and a very good year, and the fact that the fourth quarter has some distortions in timing doesn’t take away from that,” he said.

The company’s heated-tobacco products were a highlight in the quarter, and King says that Philip Morris is well on its way to hitting its unit-shipment volume target of 90 to 100 billion by 2021, thanks to ongoing strength in key markets like Russia, Japan, and Europe. He also says that iQOS’s launch in the U.S. (being spearheaded by Altria) is off to a good start, and that Philip Morris is “happy with the relationship” and believes Altria is “fully focused on maximizing the opportunity iQOS represents in the U.S.”

King argues that recent negative headlines about vaping make iQOS all the more attractive. “If you’re an adult smoker considering alternatives, iQOS has to be near the top of your list,” he said. “It’s delivering the goods in terms of scientific substantiation, it’s regulated properly through the Food and Drug Administration, consistent with protection of public health, and it’s coming from a reputable manufacturer.”

Philip Morris is down 0.2%, at $78.91, in recent trading. The S&P 500 is up 0.3%.
